metadata.case_name: Defendants 1, 2 and 2A (Appellants) v. Plaintiff-Respondent 1 and others

facts.text: On June 17, 1930, Chathilal Sah of Sahebganj, owner of a house and two golas bearing holdings Nos. 184 and 185 situated in mahalla Sahebganj, executed a will bequeathing the said property to his daughter Parbati Kuer and nephew Ram Swarup in equal shares. Under the said will Ram Swarup was to get the entire property in case Parbati Kuer died unmarried or issueless.
On July 18, 1940, Ram Swarup sold one-half of the said property to the plaintiff-respondent 1.
On July 27, 1942, the plaintiff-respondent 1 acquired under a patta some lands adjoining the said property.
The land on which the said house and golas stand is Dih-Basgit Lagani (rent-paying land).
On October 10, 1949, defendant 3 (respondent 3 herein), alleging to be the husband of the said Parbati Kuer, sold the remaining half of the disputed property to defendants 1 and 2 (appellants).
Ceremonies of pre-emption were performed on October 11, 1949, whereas the sale deed was executed and registered on October 20, 1949.

On December 10, 1949, respondent 1 filed Title Suit No. 214 of 1949 in the First Court of the Munsif at Chapra for a declaration that he has a right to pre-empt the property purchased by appellants 1 and 2 and for directing them to transfer the said property to him. Defendants 1, 2, 2A and vendor (defendant 3) were parties.

Defendants contested the suit, inter alia, on the ground that the ceremonies of pre-emption were not performed and that under the Mohamedan law the plaintiff was not entitled to pre-emption, as the land was rent-paying land.
The learned Munsif dismissed the suit on April 14, 1953.
On appeal, the Subordinate Judge of Chapra allowed the appeal and granted a decree for pre-emption in favour of the plaintiff-respondent 1.
On appeal, the Patna High Court agreed with the Subordinate Judge and dismissed the appeal (judgment dated December 10, 1958, in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 716 of 1954).
Defendants 1, 2 and 2A preferred the present appeal by special leave.
The Constitution came into force on January 26, 1950.

legal_issues.text: Whether the right of pre-emption infringes the fundamental right under Art. 19(1)(f) of the Constitution and is not saved by cl. (5) thereof.
Whether the first respondent failed to establish his title.
Whether the ceremonies of pre-emption were premature as performed on October 11, 1949, before the sale was completed on October 20, 1949.
Whether there is a right of pre-emption in respect of leasehold interest (rent-paying land) and thus a house (super-structure) standing on such land under Mohamedan law.
Scope of the right of pre-emption under the Mohamedan law as applied by custom in Bihar.

petitioner_arguments.text: The right of pre-emption infringes Art. 19(1)(f) and is not saved by cl. (5); restriction crystallized at decree post-Constitution.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 19(1)(f); Nuri Mian v. Ambica Singh

petitioner_arguments.text: First respondent failed to establish his title.
Ceremonies of pre-emption performed prematurely on October 11, 1949, before sale completed/registered on October 20, 1949.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Registration Act s. 61; Ram Saran v. Domini Kuer

petitioner_arguments.text: No right of pre-emption in respect of leasehold interest; hence no right in respect of house (mere super-structure) on such land under Mohamedan law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mohamedan law; no pre-emption for leaseholds or superstructures without land

respondent_arguments.text: Controverts the correctness of appellants' propositions on pre-emption, Art. 19, title, ceremonies, and leasehold/superstructure.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Mohamedan law recognizes pre-emption for akar (house) for peaceful enjoyment; modern evolution of leaseholds

respondent_arguments.text: Under Mohamedan law the right of pre-emption exists in the case of akar i.e., a house or mansion, irrespective of leasehold land.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Mohamedan law texts (Hedaya, Baillie's Digest); Wilson's Anglo-Muhammadan Law

court_reasoning.text: Right of pre-emption vis-a-vis co-sharers does not infringe Art. 19(1)(f); follows Bhau Ram v. Baij Nath; no distinction between related/unrelated co-sharers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Outsider means non-co-sharer; law settled between co-sharers.

court_reasoning.text: Plaintiff's title not raised below; pure question of fact, not entertainable in SC.
Prematurity of ceremonies: question of fact not raised below, no issue framed, no evidence; High Court rightly disallowed in second appeal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellants failed to raise/adduce evidence earlier.

court_reasoning.text: Pre-emptor must have full ownership (not leasehold); vendor must have proprietary right; reciprocity required; no pre-emption for leaseholds or mere superstructures without land; house on leasehold not pre-emptible as cannot take entire bargain.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Right annexed to full ownership; reciprocity defeated; superstructure disannexed becomes movable.

court_reasoning.text: General principles: right of substitution for whole property; weak right, not to be extended; Hindus in Bihar adopted Mohamedan pre-emption custom.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot rationalize or extend beyond recognized incidents.

holdings.text: Law of pre-emption vis-a-vis co-sharers does not infringe Art. 19(1)(f).
Plaintiff's title issue not for consideration.
Prematurity plea not allowable as not raised below.

No right of pre-emption in respect of leasehold interest or house (super-structure) thereon under Mohamedan law; pre-emptor cannot enforce as cannot take entire bargain due to lack of reciprocity and full ownership.
Pre-emptor must take entire bargain; partial pre-emption not generally allowed (Raghubar Dayal J. reserves opinion on exceptions).

precedents_cited.relevance: Right of pre-emption vis-a-vis co-sharers not unreasonable restriction under Art. 19(1)(f)
Registration complete under s.61 of Registration Act
Principles of pre-emption: substitution for whole, weak right

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Audh Bihari Singh Gajadhar Jaipuria
precedents_cited.relevance: Benefit/burden runs with land; full ownership required
No pre-emption for house on leasehold land
Definition of pre-emption; reciprocity; full ownership
Vested ownership required in pre-emptive tenement
Reciprocity: no pre-emption by mukarraridar against sharer
Held house sold with occupation right pre-emptible; ignored full ownership principle

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Right of pre-emption not unreasonable restriction on right to acquire/hold property

statutes_cited.name: Registration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Completion of registration when copied into records

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; decrees of Subordinate Judge and High Court set aside; decree of trial court (Munsif) dismissing suit restored. First respondent has no right to pre-empt the sale to appellants.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of trial court decree in favor of appellants

key_quotes.text: "The right of pre-emption is simply a right of substitution, but not of re-purchase i.e., the pre-emptor takes the entire bargain and steps into the shoes of the original vendee."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle limiting pre-emption to whole property

key_quotes.text: "A right of pre-emption is annexed to full ownership of property of co-sharers. It is not attached to property held on subordinate tenure, such as leases etc."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on leaseholds and superstructures

key_quotes.text: "If an outsider is introduced as a co-sharer in a property it will make common management extremely difficult and destroy the benefits of ownership in common."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justification for pre-emption among co-sharers under Art. 19
